pluralForms.explanation: Many masculine nouns and some neuter nouns add -e in the plural form. Masculine nouns with a, o, u may add an umlaut.
examples: der Tisch → die Tische
der Schuh → die Schuhe
der Arm → die Arme
der Ball → die Bälle
der Sohn → die Söhne

pluralForms.explanation: Many neuter nouns and some masculine nouns add -er in the plural form. If the vowel is a, o, u, it often gets an umlaut.
examples: das Kind → die Kinder
das Bild → die Bilder
der Mann → die Männer
das Buch → die Bücher
das Haus → die Häuser

pluralForms.explanation: Most feminine nouns and masculine nouns ending in -e add -n or -en in the plural. This pattern does not use umlauts.
examples: die Frau → die Frauen
die Tasche → die Taschen
der Student → die Studenten
die Lehrerin → die Lehrerinnen
der Junge → die Jungen

pluralForms.explanation: All feminine nouns ending in -ung (a very common word ending in German) add -en in the plural. These nouns never take an umlaut in the plural.
examples: die Wohnung → die Wohnungen
die Zeitung → die Zeitungen
die Übung → die Übungen
die Rechnung → die Rechnungen
die Erklärung → die Erklärungen

pluralForms.explanation: Many foreign words, abbreviations, and words ending in a vowel add -s in the plural. This is similar to English plurals.
examples: das Auto → die Autos
das Handy → die Handys
der Chef → die Chefs
das Hotel → die Hotels
das Hobby → die Hobbys

pluralForms.english: Some words don't change in plural (often with umlaut)
pluralForms.explanation: Some nouns have the same form in singular and plural. Many masculine nouns ending in -er, -el, or -en belong to this group, as do most neuter nouns ending in -chen or -lein.
examples: der Lehrer → die Lehrer
der Kuchen → die Kuchen
das Fenster → die Fenster
das Mädchen → die Mädchen
der Computer → die Computer

pluralForms.english: Some words only add an umlaut in plural
pluralForms.explanation: A small group of nouns (mostly masculine) form their plural by only changing the vowel to an umlaut, without adding an ending.
examples: der Vater → die Väter
die Mutter → die Mütter
der Bruder → die Brüder
der Garten → die Gärten
der Apfel → die Äpfel

pluralForms.explanation: Feminine forms of professions or people that end in -in add -nen in the plural form.
examples: die Lehrerin → die Lehrerinnen
die Ärztin → die Ärztinnen
die Studentin → die Studentinnen
die Freundin → die Freundinnen

pluralForms.explanation: Neuter nouns ending in -tum form their plural by adding -er and changing the vowel to an umlaut.
examples: das Eigentum → die Eigentümer
das Heiligtum → die Heiligtümer
das Reichtum → die Reichtümer

pluralForms.explanation: Many words of Latin or Greek origin follow special plural patterns that reflect their origin.
examples: das Museum → die Museen
das Visum → die Visa
das Praktikum → die Praktika
der Rhythmus → die Rhythmen

wordOrderBasics.rule: In main clauses, the conjugated verb is always in position 2.
wordOrderBasics.explanation: Any element can be in position 1 (subject, time, place, object). The finite verb stays in position 2.

wordOrderBasics.rule: The typical order of adverbials is Time → Manner → Place.
wordOrderBasics.explanation: This is a common and natural order in German main clauses.

examples.german: Ich gehe morgen mit dem Bus zur Arbeit.
examples.english: I go to work tomorrow by bus.

examples.german: Wir treffen uns heute Abend im Park.
examples.english: We meet this evening in the park.

wordOrderBasics.rule: 'nicht' comes before the part it negates and usually at the end of the clause, but before non-separable verb prefixes and verbal complements.
wordOrderBasics.explanation: For verbs with complements, 'nicht' usually stands before place/time or the separable prefix in main clauses.

examples.english: I am not drinking coffee today.

examples.german: Sie macht die Tür nicht auf.
examples.english: She does not open the door.

wordOrderBasics.rule: The conjugated verb goes to position 1.
wordOrderBasics.explanation: Subject follows immediately after the verb.
Common question words: wer, was, wo, wohin, woher, wann, wie, warum, was für, wie viel.

modalVerbsUsage.rule: Modal verb is conjugated in position 2; the main verb goes to the end in infinitive.
modalVerbsUsage.explanation: Common modals at A1: können, müssen, wollen, dürfen, sollen, mögen, möchten.

perfectTenseBasics.rule: Auxiliary (haben/sein) + Partizip II (past participle) at the end.
perfectTenseBasics.explanation: Use 'haben' with most verbs. Use 'sein' with verbs of movement/change of state (gehen, kommen, fahren, aufstehen) and with 'sein/bleiben/passieren'.

perfectTenseBasics.rule: ge- + verb stem + -t (regular) / irregular forms vary (gesehen, genommen, gewesen)
perfectTenseBasics.explanation: For verbs ending in -ieren, no 'ge-': studieren → studiert. For inseparable prefixes (be-, ent-, er-, ge-, miss-, ver-, zer-), no 'ge-': besuchen → besucht. Separable: prefix + ge- + stem + -t: aufmachen → aufgemacht.
